coredata.dc:title: Comment on the nature of the light-induced metastable states in nitroprussides
coredata.dc:creator: Güdel, Hans U.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The extremely long lifetimes (τ &> 107 s at T = 0 K) of light-induced metastable states (MS) in nitroprussides provide a key to understanding their nature. Both radiative (k r) and nonradiative (k nr) relaxation rates must be extremely small. In order for k nr (T = 0 K) to be smaller than 10−7 s−1, there has to be a substantial distortion of the MS with respect to the ground state (GS). The small k r (T = 0 K) < 10−7 s−1 is the result of the large displacement of GS↔MS potentials on the one hand, and a very small oscillator strength of the GS&.harr;MS transition on the other hand.

They thermally relax to the ground state (OS) above 165 K. Alternatively, a transition to the OS can be induced below 165 K by irradiation with red light (A> 620 nm) [2,3]. Very similar effects have been observed in many other salts and glasses con- taining the NP2 ion as well as in K2 [RuC15NO] [1]. This indicates that the phenomenon has a molecular basis and the M N O bond plays a crucial role. Such bistable systems are of great current interest because of their potential for optical information storage. The nature of the MS in Na2NP has been inten- sively studied by Mossbauer [4], ESR [5], Raman [2,3], JR [6], XANES [7] and optical spectroscopy [8,9], as well as calorimetric [1] and neutron-dif- fraction experiments [10]. A maximum of about 50% of NP2- ions can be converted into a MS by blue laser light in Na2NP. The N O stretching frequency is lowered from 1950 to 1832 and 1664 cm inMSl and M SIt, respectively [8]. From calorimetric measurements, it was con- cluded that MSI and MSII lie about 9000 and 6500 cm , respectively, above the ground state [8]. No EPR from the metnstable complexes has so far been detected [5]. The models suggested to account for these unusual phenomena are one-electron models based on a very early SCCC MO calculation on the NP2- ion [11 J. In this calculation, the HOMO is a mainly metal- localized orbital, and the LUMO is an antibonding ir~(NO) orbital. The MS in NP2 bave been as- cribed to this d_~pn* (NO) one-electron excitation. In the following, it is shown that an orbital model is insufficient to account for these phenomena; consid- eration of the principal relaxation mechanisms be- tween the metastable state and the ground state is found to be important. The distinction of the two metastable states, which is certainly relevant for a detailed understanding of their nature, will be ig- nored in this first step. The very existence of extremely long-lived light- induced MS in nitroprussides is remarkable in itself. The question of their longevity has not been ad- dressed so far. It is a central question, however, and we will show that it imposes severe restrictions on the identity of the metastable states. Phenomeno- logically the situation is strongly reminiscent of the light-induced singlet quintet spin-crossover transi- tions observed in some iron (II) complexes [12]. Such a formal two-electron oxidation of the iron(II) center has been postulated to account for the excited-state Raman spectra and the photo- chemical properties of NP2 - in aqueous solution at room temperature [18,191. This suggestion is appealing for two other reasons: Firstly, it explains the extremely large displacement of the MS potential which is necessary to account for the absence of nonradiative MS ~GS relaxation, see section 2 and fig. lb. Secondly, we have a close phys- ical and formal analogy in terms of electron config- urations to the spin-crossover complexes at low tem- peratures [12]: MS (t25)4( e5)2 spin-crossover complexes (t25)6 (t25)4(x4(NO))2 NP2 . (8h) The ground state is a spin singlet in both spin-cross- over and nitroprusside complexes. In the spin-cross- over complexes, the light-induced MS is a spin quin- tet; thus, the GS~-/MS transition is doubly spin- forbidden. As for the MS configuration (Sa), we can derive states with spin singlet, triplet and quintet multiplicities also from the MS configuration (Sb). We have no direct experimental evidence to identify the spin multiplicity of the MS in nitroprussides. The fact that no EPR signal has been detected so far, does not necessarily exclude a spin triplet or quintet state. It is unlikely that the MS of NP2 - derives from only one electron configuration. Configurational mixing between, e.g., the two MS configurations (Sa) and (Sb), becomes possible for a non-linear Fe N O unit. Thus, the MS can acquire some d d char- acter besides the dominant metal-to-ligand charge- transfer character. induced metastable states in numerous nitroprus- sides as well as K2 [ RuC15NO] provide a key to their understanding. The long lifetimes impose unusually severe restrictions on the rates for both radiative and nonradiative MS ~GS relaxation. The restrictions can be met by postulating an unusually large dis- placement of the MS potential with respect to the OS potential. This can plausibly be achieved if the con- figurations of OS and MS differ by two electrons. The phenomenological analogy to the light-induced metastable states in spin-crossover complexes is helpful for an understanding of the effects in the nitroprussides. The models and views presented here are rather crude and somewhat speculative. Nevertheless, we feel that the longevity of the MS in these systems is an essential feature which has not been addressed so far. Most authors have discussed these phenomena on a molecular-orbital level, thus ignoring the actual states, their dependence on the displacement coor- dinate and the transition mechanisms between the (Sa) states.
